alert.note: Alert for Grand Forks; Walsh (North Dakota) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Eastern ND and Grand Forks (Northeastern North Dakota and Northwestern Minnesota)
info.headline: Flood Warning issued April 23 at 9:32AM CDT until further notice by NWS Eastern ND and Grand Forks
info.description: ...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in North Dakota...Minnesota... Red River of the North at Drayton affecting Pembina, Kittson, Marshall and Walsh Counties. Red River of the North at Pembina affecting Pembina and Kittson Counties. Red River of the North at Oslo affecting Polk, Grand Forks, Marshall and Walsh Counties. Red River of the North at Halstad affecting Norman and Traill Counties. Red River of the North at East Grand Forks affecting Polk and Grand Forks Counties. Red River of the North at Fargo affecting Cass and Clay Counties. Red River of the North at Wahpeton affecting Richland and Wilkin Counties. Wild Rice River (ND) near Abercrombie affecting Richland County. .Red River basin river flooding to continues. Slow rises are still ongoing across the far northern basin, while the new snowmelt will result in a slower recession or long slow crest from the central and southern parts of the basin. Additional information is available at www.weather.gov. ...FLOOD WARNING FOR SNOWMELT REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL FURTHER NOTICE... * WHAT...Major flooding is occurring and major flooding is forecast. This approaches the flood of record. * WHERE...Red River of the North at Oslo. * WHEN...Until further notice. * IMPACTS...At 36.5 feet, ND State Highway 54 has water over the road. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 9:15 AM CDT Sunday the stage was 36.2 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 9:15 AM CDT Sunday was 36.2 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise to a crest of 36.4 feet tomorrow evening. - Flood stage is 26.0 feet. &&
info.instruction: Safety message - Turn around, don`t drown. Don`t travel through flooded areas. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Please report observed flooding to local emergency services or law enforcement and request they pass this information to the National Weather Service when you can do so safely.
